Looking at the logs, it seems like the memory allocation is related to CPC hal retry of initialisation. [More than one client|http://cs-stats.slipstream.volvocars.net/view/159816/analysis/CPU%2520Load%2520History?input=cloudmapreceiver%2C+vehicle_location_transmitter%2C+connectedsafety%2C+smart_charging%2C+installation_m&zoom=xaxis%3D7.331%252C180.622%26yaxis%3D-1.966%252C14.436%26xaxis2%3D7.331%252C180.622%26yaxis2%3D-1.000%252C4.000%26xaxis3%3D7.331%252C180.622%26yaxis3%3D-1.000%252C1.000%26xaxis4%3D7.331%252C180.622%26yaxis4%3D0.000%252C105.263%26yaxis5%3D21654619249.778%252C23879134094.222%26yaxis6%3D-21070381.213%252C21070381.213%26xaxis6%3D7.331%252C180.622%26xaxis7%3D7.331%252C180.622%26yaxis7%3D-55.611%252C1056.611] reports similar memory allocation and when we look at the logs, it seems quite closely related to CPC HAL retry activities such as the one below. Other than our components, we can see similar behaviour in smart_charging and installation_master for example
{code:java}
65.964085  962781-1  CMR :CPSC Error   PKCS11_Lib_Init - Failed to initialize PKCS#11 library: /opt/csp/lib/libvccpkcs11.so, error: -228

65.964108  962781-1  CMR :CPSS Warn    Failed to early initialize crypto manager - return code: -3. It will be retried in a moment
65.964246  962781-1  CMR :CPSS Info    CPS session failed. Scheduling CPS restart attempt #4 in 77 seconds...
65.964753  962781-1  CMR :CPSS Error   Failed to reinitialize CPS session
65.964757  962781-1  CMR :CPSS Info    CPS session failed, attempting restart...
65.964834  962781-1  CMR :CPST Info    SomeIP transport layer has been deactivated
65.964835  962781-1  CMR :CPSC Info    CSR process stopped successfully{code}
Investigation still ongoing;;;

2025-08-25 10:31;GASATI;Hi Patrik,

We got below update from QNX.

"I am not clear on the relation to devb-ram, but io-pkt does perform dynamic allocations (both malloc and mmap()). Most memory is associated with mbufs and clusters which is user data buffers. This can be configured on the io-pkt command line to come from typed memory. This typed memory can be limited size and dedicated to io-pkt. This will still appear to be a dynamic allocation in a kernel trace though up to the pre-determined size of the typed memory.

There are also background tasks that can dynamically allocate memory such as PF state objects or other smaller scale allocations. You could also have allocations in loaded 3rd party DLLs.

If used in combination with rlimit, current functionality allows for capping of memory, but there is not currently a mechanism to pre-allocate all required memory at the launch of the process such that there are no kernel calls attempting to allocate memory."

This is captured using [https://www.qnx.com/developers/docs/8.0/com.qnx.doc.neutrino.lib_ref/topic/p/procmgr_value_notify_add.html] which triggers a notification for change in memory. column680:
2025-07-25 09:47;DOCHERET;Work on this is ongoing. We are analyzing and cleaning up all potential places in Ethernet Diagnostics code that might allocate memory in RUN.

Currently split into three main tasks:
- *ARTHPP-28036* - Main investigation task: collecting all allocation cases, prepare log and test application.
- *ARTHPP-28058* - Fixes non-pcap allocations(std::function, unique_ptr, etc.) main part is already implemented and under review: [310266|https://csp-gerrit.volvocars.biz/c/csp/diagnostics_did_rid/+/310266]
- *ARTHPP-28063* -  Will move all pcap_* initialization to constructor so no allocations happen in RUN

Also writing a test app to help verify that nothing allocates at runtime.
More updates soon as we finalize and test the changes.;;;
column681:
2025-07-25 09:52;DOCHERET;Preliminary analysis shows that the *major source of dynamic memory allocations* is the 3rd party +*pcap*+ library, especially during:
- pcap_create()
- pcap_activate()
- pcap_compile()

Other functions like *pcap_setfilter()*, *pcap_next_ex() *or* pcap_sendpacket()* seem safe and do not allocate during runtime.

As a result, full raw socket communication init will be moved into the Diagnostics constructor (*ARTHPP-28063*) to avoid any allocations during RUN.
;;;

2024-05-28 12:55;NLU3;[~PMODILAY] [~BCHELLAG] 

When an app crashes, diagnostic-watchdog-monitor will store 2 kinds of logs to RAM path /diagnostics/:
1. to store the statistical framework log, it will collect the data from shared memory and store the data to a file using std::ofstream and std::ifstream.
2. to store the dlt log, it will invoke a process named log_querier using the system function 'posix_spawn'.

These 2 processes may allocate dynamic memory, but I am not sure how much they allocate.

Do you have comments on this?;;;
column683: 2024-05-28 12:58;PMODILAY;[~NLU3]  uds_firewall was killed on purpose with $ kill -9 <pid> i.e. by sending SIGKILL signal that generated crash, however crash wasn't the target, according to scenario tester just terminates firewall to have access to control routine. There are other ways to do that of course (e.g. just disable firewall) but I asked at least not sending SIGKILL next time, just $ kill <pid> to use SIGTERM to not generate and handle expected "crash";;;
column684:
2024-05-28 13:11;PMODILAY;[~NLU3] 

> These 2 processes may allocate dynamic memory, but I am not sure how much they allocate.

I don't know what should be considered as acceptable and by design. What we see is this "crash" handling took 224 kB additional heap memory for one already allocated buffer/memory chunk - it doesn't look as new chunk of memory; increased memory chunk didn't decrease afterwards (many minutes after) which might point at memory leakage....

The design logic is: when an app crash is detected, diag_wd_monitor will search all the metrics_* files in /dev/shmem path, read the files and then store the content into /diagnostics/statistical_framework/HPAStatisticalFramework_xxx.dmp file(watchdog_statistical_fw_handler.cpp FetchStatisticalDataAndSaveToFile()

column694:

*Status WatchdogPersistentStorage::CopyFile(csp::pmr::string const& source_file_path,*
                                           *csp::pmr::string const& destination_file_path) const noexcept {*

where you open source and destination file in classic way as ifstream/ofstream, by doing that shared memory file is mapped to the process and doubt there is a way to force system release the mapping in this case even if the file is closed (in dtor), but this mostly statistical thing, OS would reclaim that indefinitely later, when it needs it, important that is that reference count is zero as should be in this case. 

In such a case we can vote for deviation to allow such grow with ceiling as you say, the ceiling would be 224kb x 2 on condition there is no growing at all after that.

Another option is to not use C++ I/O at all and even do one copy instead of two (file -> buffer -> file) with the help of mmap call, the idea is to mmap both files and then get addresses to memory to do memcpy() from one memory to another ...  e.g. [https://stackoverflow.com/questions/26582920/mmap-memcpy-to-copy-file-from-a-to-b]

2025-11-10 10:18;HARGEMID;Hi [~LPATRIK1] & [~FYE4], as seen in the comments of the FR, this is happening in all baselines tested of release candidate branch 10.2, and were seen in master when we were testing it there, so if it has not been fixed it will still be present and it happens every time the VCU goes to UM Driving. We can provide our rigs as test environment as we have been doing for other developers trying to fix applications allocating memory such as yours. We could also provide contacts of other developers that have been successful fixing their issues as maybe they have information that would make it easier for you to identify what is going on.

Regarding the environment to test, you can merge your code to your master and make a patchset towards cs-software-product. That would let us build vbf that creates a blob in Victoria which we can trigger the automatic test on.

If you want to try reproducing the issue in you own environment, I can explain the check we are doing:
 * Turn on VCU and wait for all applications to be in "RUN" state
 * Check the initial memory allocated by all apps by running the following command in HPA: _hogs -i 1 -S -c -s 1 -l 64_
 * Go to UM Driving, get some speed, drive for 1 minute and park
 * Check the final memory allocated by all apps by running the following command in HPA: _hogs -i 1 -S -c -s 1 -l 64_
 * Compare the allocated memory of each app from the initial value that we got to the final one.

Let me know if you have any there is anything else we could do to help;;;
